articles.headline: Bloomberg News’s Dilemma: How to Cover a Boss Seeking the Presidency
articles.snippet: Michael Bloomberg’s rise in the polls has increased the pressure on political reporters employed by his news outlet.
articles.abstract: Michael Bloomberg’s rise in the polls has increased the pressure on political reporters employed by his news outlet.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Micklethwait, the editor in chief of Bloomberg News, walked into his Washington bureau on a Friday morning in December with a daunting task: explaining to his political reporters how to cover a presidential campaign when the boss is a candidate.

articles.headline: How Millennials Could Make the Fed’s Job Harder
articles.snippet: They love the idea of retiring early. That could diminish Federal Reserve’s firepower.
articles.abstract: They love the idea of retiring early. That could diminish Federal Reserve’s firepower.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “They say millennials are lazy,” billboards plastered across 15 major cities declared last summer. “Retire early and prove them right.”

articles.headline: Jeff Bezos Commits $10 Billion to Address Climate Change
articles.snippet: The world’s richest man unveiled a fund to help climate scientists and activists, an escalation of his philanthropic efforts.
articles.abstract: The world’s richest man unveiled a fund to help climate scientists and activists, an escalation of his philanthropic efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive and the world’s richest man, said on Monday that he was committing $10 billion to address the climate crisis in a new initiative he called the Bezos Earth Fund.

articles.headline: Apple Signals Coronavirus’s Threat to Global Businesses
articles.snippet: Supply is a problem, the company warned, as factories slowly reopen in China, and demand is down, too, with stores there still mostly closed.
articles.abstract: Supply is a problem, the company warned, as factories slowly reopen in China, and demand is down, too, with stores there still mostly closed.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple on Monday became one of the first companies to reveal how the coronavirus that has gripped China was affecting its business, saying it was cutting its sales expectations for this quarter, which a month ago it had projected to be robust.

articles.headline: As Afghan Soldier Kills 2 Americans, Peace Talks Forge Ahead
articles.snippet: This time when U.S. soldiers are killed by an Afghan, Trump does not call off talks with the Taliban. Is ending the war the only way to end these killings?
articles.abstract: This time when U.S. soldiers are killed by an Afghan, Trump does not call off talks with the Taliban. Is ending the war the only way to end these killings?
articles.lead_paragraph: NANGARHAR, Afghanistan — President Trump stood in a misty drizzle at Dover Air Force Base as the remains of America’s latest two casualties in the long war in Afghanistan arrived home.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal, Katie Rogers, Zabihullah Ghazi and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Huawei Is Winning the Argument in Europe, as the U.S. Fumbles to Develop Alternatives
articles.snippet: Germany seems poised to follow Britain in letting the Chinese maker build next-generation networks, despite last appeals from the United States.
articles.abstract: Germany seems poised to follow Britain in letting the Chinese maker build next-generation networks, despite last appeals from the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s global campaign to prevent its closest allies from using Huawei, the Chinese telecom giant, in the next generation of wireless networks has largely failed, with foreign leaders publicly rebuffing the United States argument that the firm poses an unmanageable security threat.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and David McCabe

articles.headline: Boy Scouts Seek Bankruptcy to Survive a Deluge of Sex-Abuse Claims
articles.snippet: The nonprofit group, which counts more than two million youth participants, follows Catholic dioceses and U.S.A. Gymnastics in seeking bankruptcy protection amid sex-abuse cases.
articles.abstract: The nonprofit group, which counts more than two million youth participants, follows Catholic dioceses and U.S.A. Gymnastics in seeking bankruptcy protection amid sex-abuse cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hoping to contain a deluge of sexual-abuse lawsuits, the Boy Scouts of America took shelter in bankruptcy court on Tuesday, filing for Chapter 11 protection that will let the group keep operating while it grapples with questions about the future of the century-old Scouting movement.

articles.headline: Pessimistic Outlook in Russia Slows Investment, and the Economy
articles.snippet: Growth has slowed to well below the global average as economists point to low spending by the government and the private sector.
articles.abstract: Growth has slowed to well below the global average as economists point to low spending by the government and the private sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Last year, Russia set a goal to quicken its economic expansion — to grow faster than the world as a whole — as a way to secure the country’s position as a dominant global power.

articles.headline: In Coronavirus Fight, China Sidelines an Ally: Its Own People
articles.snippet: The outbreak has exposed the powerlessness of private charities, civic groups and others who could help the effort but whom the Communist Party considers rivals.
articles.abstract: The outbreak has exposed the powerlessness of private charities, civic groups and others who could help the effort but whom the Communist Party considers rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hospitals in Wuhan and surrounding Hubei Province have been making urgent pleas to the Chinese people for three weeks as the new coronavirus ripples through the country: Send more protective gear.

articles.headline: Michael Bloomberg Leans Left With Plan to Rein In Wall St.
articles.snippet: Some of the billionaire’s proposals wouldn’t be out of place for his more progressive presidential rivals.
articles.abstract: Some of the billionaire’s proposals wouldn’t be out of place for his more progressive presidential rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday offered his proposals for regulating Wall Street, where he made his billions, promising a return of Obama-era oversight if elected president and invoking the name of one of his rivals, Senator Elizabeth Warren, in an attempt to connect with the Democratic Party’s progressive wing.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Michael J. de la Merced, Emily Flitter and Stacy Cowley
